steps.title: Clean out the insides of your heels with a baby wipe.
steps.content: Clean out the insides of your heels with a baby wipe. Use an unscented baby wipe to get rid of dirt and grime from the toes and heel part of your shoes. Use pressure and wipe in a circular motion to get rid of everything. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe the outside of your heels with a sudsy cleanser.
steps.content: Wipe the outside of your heels with a sudsy cleanser. Wet a clean washcloth with warm water and apply 1 drop of mild cleanser, like dish soap or detergent. Wipe down the outside of your heels with the cloth, paying special attention to any dirty or muddy areas. Remove any dirt from the underside of your heels last. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use a rubber cleaning stone to get rid of any remaining dirt.
steps.content: Use a rubber cleaning stone to get rid of any remaining dirt. Hold a rubber cleaning stone in 1 hand and swipe it down your heel in 1 direction. Pay special attention to the area around your toes and the back of your heels. [3] X Research source You can purchase a rubber cleaning stone at most leather shops or shoe stores.

steps.title: Brush your heels with a suede brush.
steps.content: Brush your heels with a suede brush. Brush your heels all over to restore their texture and remove any remaining dirt. Suede brushes are soft and made specifically for this material, so they won’t hurt your shoes. [4] X Research source You can find suede brushes at most leather stores.

steps.title: Brush the outside of the heels with a soft brush.
steps.content: Brush the outside of the heels with a soft brush. Remove large dirt and debris with a soft-bristled brush. Gently swipe the brush across the outside of your heels in a circular motion. [5] X Research source Soft brushes won’t damage the soft leather material of your heels. Leather heels usually look slightly textured and feel soft to the touch.

steps.title: Wipe down the outside and bottom with a damp cloth and soap.
steps.content: Wipe down the outside and bottom with a damp cloth and soap. Dip a cloth into warm water and add 1 drop of mild dish soap. Rub the cloth across the outside of your heels, and pay special attention to the toes and any dirty areas. [6] X Expert Source Trent Potter Shoe Care & Repair Specialist Expert Interview. 22 April 2021. Run the cloth over the bottoms of your heels last to remove mud and dirt. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Rub the shoes again with a clean, damp cloth.
steps.content: Rub the shoes again with a clean, damp cloth. Get a different cloth slightly wet with warm water. Wipe down your heels with the cloth to remove any soap residue that is left over. [8] X Research source Leaving soap on your shoes could cause them to dry with streaks. If you notice scuffs or damage near the toes of your high heels, apply some tinted shoe cream to cover it up. [9] X Expert Source Trent Potter Shoe Care & Repair Specialist Expert Interview. 22 April 2021.

steps.title: Wipe down the insides of your heels with baby wipes.
steps.content: Wipe down the insides of your heels with baby wipes. Grab an unscented baby wipe and clean out the inside of your heels. Pay special attention to the toes and heel area, as those are usually the dirtiest. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Let your heels air dry.
steps.content: Let your heels air dry. Set your leather heels in a cool, dry spot and let them dry for about 1 hour. Keep them out of the sun to avoid any fading or damage. Make sure the insides of your heels are completely dry before you wear them again. [11] X Research source Never use heat to speed up the drying process. Heat damages leather and could make your heels shrink or warp.

steps.title: Wipe out the inside with baby wipes.
steps.content: Wipe out the inside with baby wipes. Grab an unscented baby wipe and use it to wipe out the inside of your heels. Pay special attention to the heel and toe areas where your feet touch the shoes the most to get rid of any dirt or grime that has built up on the inside of your shoes. [12] X Research source Let the insides of your heels dry before you put them on again. Patent leather is a slick, shiny material that is often all black or all white.

steps.title: Rub your shoes with a cotton cloth.
steps.content: Rub your shoes with a cotton cloth. Grab a clean cotton cloth and rub the outside of your heels in a circular motion to get rid of dirt and debris. Pay special attention to any areas that are really dirty, like the toes or backs of your heels. [13] X Research source You can also use a microfiber towel to clean off your heels.

steps.title: Buff patent leather cleaner into your heels.
steps.content: Buff patent leather cleaner into your heels. Apply 1 to 2 drops of patent leather cleaner to a clean cloth. Rub the cloth into the outside of your heels in a circular motion. [14] X Expert Source Trent Potter Shoe Care & Repair Specialist Expert Interview. 22 April 2021. Cover the entire outside of your shoes to make them look shiny and new. [15] X Research source You can find patent leather cleaner at most shoe stores.

steps.title: Let your shoes dry for 5 minutes, then buff off the cleaner.
steps.content: Let your shoes dry for 5 minutes, then buff off the cleaner. Set your shoes in a clean, dry place, and set a time for 5 minutes. Take a clean cloth and run it over your shoes in a circular motion to buff off the cleaner and remove it. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Buff out scuffs using rubbing alcohol on a cotton swab.
steps.content: Buff out scuffs using rubbing alcohol on a cotton swab. Dip a cotton swab into rubbing alcohol. Rub it on any scuffs or water spots on the outside of your shoes in a small circular motion for about 1 minute until the scuff disappears. [17] X Research source Scuffs and water spots on patent leather usually look white or dull.

steps.title: Wipe out the insides of your heels with a baby wipe.
steps.content: Wipe out the insides of your heels with a baby wipe. Use an unscented baby wipe to remove any dirt and grime from the inside of your heel. Pay special attention to the toes and back of the heel where dirt might accumulate. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Brush off dirt and dust with a soft-bristled brush.
steps.content: Brush off dirt and dust with a soft-bristled brush. Use caution so you don’t push the dirt back into the shoe. Brush in a downwards motion to get rid of the large debris. [19] X Research source Satin heels feel slick and shiny and may not be super soft to the touch.

steps.title: Dab the dirty areas with cold water.
steps.content: Dab the dirty areas with cold water. Wet a clean washcloth with cold water from your sink and gently blot the area with your washcloth. Try not to rub or swipe at the dirt, or you could push the grime back into the satin. [20] X Research source Cold water is more gentle on satin and won’t harm the fibers of your heels.

steps.title: Add hand soap to your cloth if you need a deeper clean.
steps.content: Add hand soap to your cloth if you need a deeper clean. If the cold water wasn’t enough to remove the dirt from your satin heels, dip your wet cloth into a small amount of hand soap. Blot the dirty area with your soapy cloth. [21] X Research source Use mild hand soap that doesn’t have any added scents or dyes for the best results. You can use hand soap and water to wash off the soles of your heels if they are dirty.

steps.title: Pat the area with cold water to rinse out the soap.
steps.content: Pat the area with cold water to rinse out the soap. Wet a different area of your cloth with cold water. Gently dab the soapy area to pick up the majority of the hand soap and remove it from your shoes. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Dab the shoes with a dry cloth and allow them to air dry.
steps.content: Dab the shoes with a dry cloth and allow them to air dry. Grab a clean, dry cloth and gently blot the wet areas of your shoes. Try to pick up the majority of the water without rubbing or swiping your cloth. Let your shoes sit in a cool, dry place to dry all the way before wearing them again. [23] X Research source If you live in a humid climate, set up a dehumidifier to remove some of the moisture from your air to make your shoes dry quickly.

steps.title: Wipe down the insides of your heels with a baby wipe.
steps.content: Wipe down the insides of your heels with a baby wipe. Take an unscented baby wipe and quickly wipe out the inside of your heels. Pay special attention to the toes, as this is usually the dirtiest area of your shoes. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Wet a toothbrush with warm water.
steps.content: Wet a toothbrush with warm water. Fill a bowl with water that is just warmer than lukewarm. Dip a new, clean toothbrush into the water to get the bristles wet. [25] X Research source Try keeping a few new toothbrushes around that are dedicated to cleaning your heels. Canvas and cotton shoes feel like a typical T-shirt and may be brightly colored or patterned.

steps.title: Dip your toothbrush into some baking soda.
steps.content: Dip your toothbrush into some baking soda. Pour 1 tbsp (14 g) of baking soda into a small dish. Dip the wet toothbrush bristles into the baking soda to pick up a little bit on the end of the toothbrush. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the dirty areas of your shoes in a circular motion.
steps.content: Scrub the dirty areas of your shoes in a circular motion. Use the toothbrush to gently scrub dirt and grime off of your heels. Dip the toothbrush back into the water if you need to remove large chunks of dirt or mud. [27] X Research source

steps.title: Dip a cloth into dish soap and water.
steps.content: Dip a cloth into dish soap and water. Take a clean rag and wet it with lukewarm water. Then, dip 1 corner into a small bowl of mild dish soap. [28] X Research source Try to use dish soap that doesn’t have any added dyes or fragrances.

steps.title: Wipe any excess mud or dirt downwards off the shoe.
steps.content: Wipe any excess mud or dirt downwards off the shoe. Apply gentle pressure with your rag to get rid of all the dirt and grime. Swipe your rag in a downwards motion so you don’t press any dirt back into the material of your heel, and use your rag to wipe off any dirt from the bottom of your heels as well. [29] X Research source If there is still mud or dirt left on your shoe, use the toothbrush and baking soda again.
